The present study attempts to predict the logp for 22 compounds as part of SAMPL7 challenge.
Our workflow consists of four steps as follows: 1)data collection and molecular descriptor calculation
column4: and 4)ensemble prediction. To build prediction models
column5: we applied machine learning approaches such as random forest
column7: and 1D-CNN methods.   We also applied ensembl predictions by combining three prediction models. In order to build prediction models

column1: Data collection and molecular descriptor calculation
We collected 2 different datasets which are Martel set (n=707) and PHYSPROP(n=11657) and calculated more than 4000 molecular descriptors may represent logp values.
We applied a meta learning model which utilized already existing logp prediction values
Since we calculated more than 4000 molecular descriptors
column2: it is better to select significant descriptors for appropriately representing logp as well as avoiding model overfitting. We recursively eliminate less significant features with the generation of multiple random forest models in each iteration. We obtained 101 features for Martel dataset and 190 features for PHYSPROP dataset to build predictive models.

column1: We applied an ensemble prediction employing three different prediction models
column4: and 1D-CNN respectively. We also applied 5 fold cross validation and each machine learning model predicts the logp values by averaging the five models from each fold.

column1: As our model calculates logs we convert it to kcal/mol unit by using the equation: logpow <- ((deltaGw - deltaGo)/(RT))*loge
